lines.content: Duke is a command-line (CLI) chatbot application that helps you keep track of your tasks.
- Ensure that you have Java 11 installed in your computer. To check your java version, open your terminal and type the following command `java --version` and the following should show up:
- Download the latest `.jar` file from [here](https://github.com/ong-ck/ip/releases). You may move it to a directory of your choice in your computer.
- Open the terminal in the directory that the `.jar` file is stored and type the following command `java -jar ip.jar`. A welcome message should pop up as follows:
What can I do for you?
- You may start using Duke following the instructions in this user guide!
You can add tasks, of three different types - todo, deadline and event - into your list to keep track of them.
You can print out your list of items for viewing.
You can mark/unmark your task as done/undone to track completion.
You can find the tasks within your list that matches a keyword.
You can delete tasks in your list that you do not need to keep track of anymore.
### Saving tasks in your list locally
Your list of tasks are saved regularly at every update and after exiting the program. The saved tasks are also loaded at the start of the program.
You can add tasks, of three different types - todo, deadline and event - into your list to keep track of them.

Note: For `deadline` tasks, if you have input your `DEADLINE_OF_TASK` in the following format `yyyy-mm-dd` (e.g., `2019-10-15`), it will be reformatted to a different format `mmm dd yyyy` e.g., (`Oct 15 2019`). Formats other than the above will not reformat the `DEADLINE_OF_TASK`.
Feedback will be given by Duke to inform you that your task has been added.
Great job adding a new task!
Great job adding a new task!
You can print out your list of items for viewing.
Note: The command `list` should not have any other keywords after the command. An error message will return if other keywords are added.
Example of usage and expected outcome:
The items added will be printed out as a list. If there are no items in the list, a message will be printed instead.
Here are the tasks in your list:
You can mark your task as done to track completion.
Note: The `INDEX` must be a integer within the indexes present when `list` command is executed.
The task at `INDEX` will be marked. It will be shown with an 'X' in the checkbox when the list is printed.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Here are the tasks in your list:
You can unmark your task as undone to track completion.
Note: The `INDEX` must be a integer within the indexes present when `list` command is executed.
The task at `INDEX` will be unmarked. It will be shown with an space in the checkbox when the list is printed.
Here are the tasks in your list:
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Here are the tasks in your list:
You can find the tasks within your list that matches a keyword.
All tasks saved that matches the `KEYWORD` will be printed as a list.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Here are the tasks in your list:
You can delete tasks in your list that you do not need to keep track of anymore.
Note: The `INDEX` must be a integer within the indexes present when `list` command is executed.
The task at `INDEX` will be removed from the list of saved tasks.
Here are the tasks in your list:
OK, the following task has been removed:
Here are the tasks in your list:
Example of usage and expected outcome:
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!

todo NAME_OF_TASK
deadline NAME_OF_TASK /by DEADLINE_OF_TASK
event NAME_OF_EVENT /from EVENT_START /to EVENT_END

todo TaskA
deadline TaskB /by 8 May 2023 6pm
deadline TaskC /by 2023-01-01
event EventD /from 1 May /to 2 May
* A Duke object handles the running of the Duke chatbot application.
* The class constructor that instantiates the Ui,
* It uses the file path of the data file to load previous data into the TaskList.
* @param filePath The file path of the data file.
* Starts the Duke application by printing a welcome message.
* Closes the Duke application by saving the data and printing a closing message.
System.out.println("Please input a list index to mark!");
System.out.println("The list index you have input is not in the list!");
System.out.println("Please input a list index to mark!");
System.out.println("The list index you have input is not in the list!");
System.out.println("Please input a list index to delete!");
System.out.println("The list index you have input is not in the list!");
* The Storage object handles the creation of the data file
* as well as manages the loading and writing of the data file.
* The class constructor that instantiates the Storage object with a specified file path.
* @param filePath The file path of the data file.
* Loads the data from the data file into a TaskList object.
* If the data file or folder is missing a new folder and/or data file will be created.
* If the data file is empty, an empty TaskList will be returned.
* Creates a new data file and folder if needed.
* Writes data to the data file using the list of tasks stored in TaskList object.
* The Parser object handles the user input and
* allows the program to understand the commands given by the user.
private static Scanner inputScanner = new Scanner(System.in);
* Reads the user input and saves it in parts as command and input parameter.
* Returns the user command from the user input.
* Returns the user input parameter from the user input,
* if no input parameter, an empty string is returned.
* @return The user input parameter or an empty string.
* The Ui object represents the user interface
* that interacts with the user by producing output.
System.out.println("Hello! I'm Duke\nWhat can I do for you?");
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Echos the user input by printing it back to the terminal.
* @param userInput The user input that will be echoed.
* Prints a message to inform the user that they have input an invalid command.
System.out.println("You have entered an unknown command! Please try again!");
* An exception for the issue when the task description is missing in the task input.
* The Deadline object represents the task with a deadline that the user adds.
* It contains a LocalDate object that stores the date.
* The class constructor that sets the description of the deadline.
* @param description The description of the deadline.
* Formats the deadline into a specific String.
* It also reformats the date if possible.
* @return A formatted String representing the deadline.
* The Event object represents the event that the user adds.
* It contains a start and end date/time.
* The class constructor that sets the description of the event.
* @param description The description of the event.
* Formats the event into a specific String.
* @return A formatted String representing the event.
* The Task object represents the task that the user adds.
* It contains the description of the task, whether the task is done and the type of the task.
* A class constructor that sets the description of the task,
* the default value of false for whether it is done, and
* the task type as the default value of TODO.
* @param description The description of the task.
* Sets the task as done or undone.
* @param isDone The boolean value of whether the task is done or undone.
* Checks and returns a string to indicate whether the task is done.
* @return A String "X" if the task is done and " " if the task is undone.
* Checks the task type and returns a specific String that corresponds to the task type.
* @return A String indicating the task type.
* Formats the task into a specific String.
* @return A formatted String representing the task.
* A TaskList object represents the list of tasks stored by the user.
* Loading a task item into the list of tasks from the data stored in the data file.
* @param markIndicator the indicator to determine if the task is marked or unmarked.
* @param taskDescription the description of the task to be loaded.
* @param taskType the type of the task that is to be loaded into the list of tasks.
public static void loadTask(String markIndicator, String taskDescription, TaskType taskType) {
* Reformat the list of tasks into a single string to be written into the data file.
* @return A string representing the list of tasks.
* Adds a new task into the list of tasks.
* @param taskDescription The description of the task.
* @param taskType The type of the task.
* @throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException If some parameters are missing while adding the task.
* @throws EmptyTaskInputException If task description is empty.
public static void addTask(String taskDescription, TaskType taskType) {
System.out.println("You are missing some parameters in the input! Please try again!");
System.out.println("Your input description cannot be empty! Please try again!");
System.out.println("Great job adding a new task!");
* Removes a task from the list of tasks based on the index of the task when printed.
* @param index The index of the task.
* @throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException If index provided is not within the list of tasks.
System.out.println("OK, the following task has been removed:");
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
System.out.println("You have no tasks at the moment. Please add some tasks!");
* Find tasks in the list of tasks that matches certain keyword(s) and prints out all matching tasks.
* @param string The keyword(s) that is used to find matches in the tasks.
System.out.println("Please input a keyword to search!");
// Checks if any matches are found
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
System.out.println("No matches are found for your keyword, please search another keyword!");
System.out.println("You have no tasks at the moment. Please add some tasks before searching!");
* Marks a task as done based on the index of the printed list of tasks.
* @param index The index of the task.
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* Marks a task as undone based on the index of the printed list of tasks.
* @param index The index of the task.
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");
* Types of tasks that can be stored by the user.
